title: Create and Switch to a Branch in One Command
description:
Git allows you to create and switch to a new branch in a single command.

Create a new branch called 'feature-branch' and switch to it in one command.
hints: Use 'git checkout -b feature-branch' to create and switch to a new branch in one command.
In newer Git versions, you could also use 'git switch -c feature-branch'.

title: Merge a Branch
description:
Merging combines the changes from one branch into another.

Switch to the 'master' branch and merge the 'feature' branch into it.
hints: First use 'git checkout master' to switch to the master branch.
Then use 'git merge feature' to merge the feature branch into master.

title: No Fast-Forward Merge
description:
Sometimes you want to preserve the branch history when merging.

Merge the 'feature' branch into 'master' with the --no-ff flag to prevent fast-forwarding.
hints: First use 'git checkout master' to switch to the master branch.
Then use 'git merge --no-ff feature' to merge with a commit even if fast-forward is possible.

title: Resolve a Merge Conflict
description:
Sometimes changes in different branches conflict with each other.

Resolve the merge conflict between 'feature' and 'master' branches by merging 'feature' into 'master' and fixing the conflict in 'shared-file.txt'.

You can use the special game commands:
- 'resolve current shared-file.txt' to keep the current branch version
- 'resolve incoming shared-file.txt' to use the incoming branch version
hints: First checkout the master branch with 'git checkout master'
Try to merge with 'git merge feature' - this will show the conflict
Resolve the conflict with either 'resolve current shared-file.txt' or 'resolve incoming shared-file.txt'
After resolving, use 'git add shared-file.txt' to mark it as resolved
Complete the merge with 'git commit -m "Merge conflict resolved"'

title: Abort an In-Progress Merge
description:
Sometimes a merge goes wrong and you need to return to the state before the merge began.

Check out the 'master' branch, attempt to merge the 'feature' branch (which will cause a conflict), then abort the merge using any appropriate Git command.
hints: First use 'git checkout master' to switch to the master branch
Then use 'git merge feature' to start the merge (which will cause a conflict)
To abort the merge and return to the pre-merge state, use 'git merge --abort'
Alternative solutions include 'git reset --hard HEAD' or 'git checkout -f'

title: View a Graphical Log of Branches and Commits
description:
The regular git log command shows commits in a linear fashion. For repositories with multiple branches, it can be helpful to visualize the branch structure.

Use git log with the --graph flag to display a graphical representation of the commit history. You can also try additional flags like --oneline for compact output and --all to see all branches.
hints: Use 'git log --graph' to show a text-based graphical representation of the commit history.
Try combining flags: 'git log --graph --oneline --all' for an even more useful view.

title: List All Branches in a Repository
description:
To manage your repository effectively, you need to know what branches exist.

Use the appropriate Git command to list all branches in the repository.
hints: The command to list all branches is simply 'git branch' with no additional arguments.
Your current branch will be marked with an asterisk (*) in the output.

title: Rename the Current Branch
description:
Sometimes your branch names need to change to better reflect their purpose.

Rename the current branch from 'master' to 'main'.
hints: Use 'git branch -m main' to rename your current branch.
You can also use the longer form 'git branch --move main'.

title: Force Delete a Branch
description:
Sometimes you need to delete a branch even when it has unmerged changes.

Create a branch called 'feature-temp' and add a commit to it. Then switch back to master and force delete the 'feature-temp' branch.

Use the special game command 'createfile filename content' to create a file (e.g., 'createfile newfile.txt This is content').
hints: First create a branch with 'git branch feature-temp' and switch to it with 'git checkout feature-temp'
Create a file using 'createfile newfile.txt Some content'
Stage the file with 'git add newfile.txt'
Commit it with 'git commit -m "Add new file"'
Switch back to master with 'git checkout master'
Try to delete with 'git branch -d feature-temp' - you'll see it fails
Force delete with 'git branch -D feature-temp'

title: List Merged and Unmerged Branches
description:
Git allows you to filter branches by their merge status relative to the current branch.

Use the appropriate Git commands to:
1. List branches that have been merged into the current branch
2. List branches that have not been merged into the current branch
hints: Use 'git branch --merged' to see branches that have been merged into the current branch.
Use 'git branch --no-merged' to see branches that have not been merged into the current branch.
